2.subquestion: Now we can answer the question: What are the quantities of crackers and cakes each friend receives?

subanswer.text: Since Matthew is dividing the items equally among 28 friends, each friend will receive 13 / 28 crackers (rounded down) and 15 / 28 cakes (rounded down), approximately 0.464 crackers and 0.536 cakes respectively. However, as crackers and cakes cannot be split, rounding down would not provide a fair share, as it implies some people get nothing. To divide fairly, Matthew should give out 1 cracker to each person first, then distribute any leftover crackers; then do the same with cakes, but only after distributing all available crackers to ensure everyone gets at least one item. But since both 13 and 15 are not perfectly divisible by 28, we need to determine how many crackers or cakes are left over after distribution. There will be 13 - 28 = -15 (which means 15 extra crackers) and 15 - 28 = -13 (meaning 13 fewer cakes). We should use these leftovers in such a way that every single person gets an item. So the distribution should be 1 cracker per person and 0 cakes per person until all 28 people have received a cracker, leaving 15 extra crackers. Then give each person one cake (except those who already got their cake), giving 13 fewer people a cake. This results in the following division: Each friend gets 1 cracker and 0 cakes, leaving 15 people without a cake and 1 cracker left over. Then each of the remaining people gets one cake. This leaves 13 people still missing a cake. Since Matthew only has 15 cakes, he gives 1 extra cake to 7 of the remaining 13 people (because 14 divided by 2 equals 7). So the final distribution is 1 cracker to each friend, 0 cakes to the first 21 friends and 1 cake to the next 7. The answer is 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker, 0cake, 1cracker.
